38670715.review:
[b]Princess Remedy in a World of Hurt[/b] is a mix between RPG and bullethell. In this game you will travel around the world(Final Fantasy style) and heal everyone(bullethell minigame). It's a nice little game which can be completed under an hour, but it has a lot of replayability value as it features 66 different endings and also some interesting secrets which you wouldn't find on your first playthrough.

[b]Pros:[/b]
- Free
- Outstanding soundtrack
- Lots of secrets
- Awesome humor

[b]Cons:[/b]
- Short

If you're not afraid of pixelated indie games, then this is recommended for you.

38659776.review: A short and charming cross between simple RPG mechanics and exciting battles reminiscent of bullet-hells and horizontal shooters. 38596700.review:
Este juego está muy completo, entretenido y alucinante. A pesar de ser un juego gratuito, tiene una jugabilidad bastante agradable y demandante de habilidad y destreza en la toma de decisiones. Es un juego que recuerda mucho a la época dorada de los videojuegos del siglo XX, sin elementos demasiado desarrollados pero bien realizados, que dan mucho a la imaginación para pensar, idealizar y simular. 
Princess Remedy in a World of Hurt definitivamente cautiva el corazón del jugador porque la historia sobre seres que sanan en un mundo de dolor realmente se siente en todo el juego. El solo imaginarte que debes llegar a todos los rincones del mundo (del juego xD) te da para pensar en una exploración y aventura que no te aburrirá, pensando que puedes desarrollar al personaje sin esfuerzo. 

Gracias a este juego, me he sentido atraído por comprar su secuela para descubrir más información, historias y aventuras de la chica Remedy [spoiler](Remedio)[/spoiler] :)

Хорошая сказка с отличным саундтреком, проходится за час, оставляет хорошие воспоминания :D
Главная героиня - принцесса Ремеди, прилетает в Мир Боли, где ее миссией будет лечение каждого нуждающегося.
Геймплей - ходим по разным биомам, лечим жителей. Лечение проходит путем расстрела всех бактерий, за каждого выздоровевшего мы получаем одно сердце (сердца нужны для прохода в следующий биом).
80% игры проходится легко (играл на высокой сложности), но над некоторыми "больными" приходится серьезно попотеть)
Итог: короткая динамичная игра в духе старых игровых приставок, божественный саундтрек, рекомендую!

10 свадеб с туалетной бумагой из 10

36354596.review:
“...В какой бы дом я ни вошел, я войду туда для пользы больного…”
 
Жила была марсианская принцесса Ремеди (Лекарство), она училась на медика, закончив медицинский, ее мать попросила сгонять помочь в соседнее королевство в Мире Боли, чтобы вылечить тамошнего принца и заодно скилл лечения поднять, потому как ее подруга после отправки к нему куда-то пропала, а значит настала очередь Ремеди.

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=840302249
 
Прибыв на место Ремеди быстренько поднимает индивидуальный скилл до невероятных высот, леча всех подряд и улитку, и червячка, и паучка, цветочек, больную челюсть, кролика, мертвеца, сифилис, кентавра, геймера, ужасного монстра, охранника, дельфина, одинокую подругу, лорда тьмы, целую гору остального народа, ну и наконец принца.
 
Лечение всего живого происходит в режиме Bullet Hell’а, мы буквально закидываем болячки пластырями, уколами и целебными пузырьками, еще у нас есть ограниченные в запасе зелья с лечением (гранаты), которые просто швыряются по прямой.
 
Болячек много и все они по-разному ведут себя, из стандартных, наверное, сложнее всего было лечить разбитое сердце. Финальный босс выглядит, ну прям, как вылитый босс из Undertale, такой же страхолюдный.
 
После победы над ним, принц разрешает взять кого угодно из вылеченных в королевстве в супруги и править королевством с выбранным персонажем.

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=911388840
 
Игра не очень долгая, проходится очень быстро за час, еще за 30 минут вы по переженитесь на всех персонажах, чтобы увидеть все концовки, коих тут 66, правда отличаются они одним предложением по сути то...
 
Подводя итог, Принцесса Ремеди — это замечательная, динамичная игра, которая не надоедает и проходится очень быстро, но с одним недостатком, а именно ужасное разрешение, до сих пор не понимаю, что мешало сделать внутриигровые пиксели побольше, ведь даже невозможно нормальный скриншот сделать!
 
+Вылечи их всех!
+Динамичная
+Короткая
+Бесплатная
 
-Слишком маленькое разрешение
 
9 из 10

Кураторская группа: http://steamcommunity.com/groups/IKCB

36309543.review: Bullet hell turned wonderful via healing powers. Super quick, super fun for a delightful and refreshing game. Wonderful original NES vibes with a really fun soundtrack. It's easy to jump into, but difficult to master, definitely worth a try if you've got a spare hour!

36247839.review:
Now here is one awesome shooter. Here you control Princess Remedy, a healer, who is out into this world to heal all the people. It has a nice ZX Spectrum style to it, graphically. Maybe audio, but I am not familar enough with that platform. None the less, in jRPG-like overworld you just walk around, discovering hidden passages, grabbing powerups from chests and interacting with NPCs to start the healing proccess.

And healing process? Something new and smart? Naaaah, it's just your usual shooter. Think of Robotron 2084. Sorta. You run around arena, killing all enemies. Shooting non-stop where you are facing. There is no separate control for movement and aiming, so it's sorta old-school.

What makes it awesome is how quirky and fast-paced this is. The lenght is just right for the humor it has The battles come and go fast as well. It's all super fancy.

36048624.review:
If you enjoy bullet hell shoot em ups, then this game is a must play.  The game is as hard or as easy as you set your difficulty to and depending if you open any chests. The chests in this game are littered throughout Hurtland (and space) and each one of them will have something good inside for you. The game steadily gets harder (provided you dont have everything yet) and your skills will be tested. 
The game frankly looks like an NES title, or a DOS game but with more colors. Its pleasing to my nostalgic eyes.
The story isnt much, you've just graduated fron Healing School and right off the bat you're needed to go down to Hurtland and heal the Prince.

(Please stop connecting this game to Undertale when Undertalr didnt even come out when this game got aproved on Greenlight) Anyways, I wont spoil the final boss. The reason why this review wasnt so detailed is because there would be major spoilers for the entire game, and I dont wanna ruin that for anybody.

I give this game a 6/10.

Vous voulez assassiner votre famille, mais vous en manquez le courage? Jouez à ce "jeu" une heure et vous serez tout à fait dans l'état d'esprit pour le faire! 

Au début, tout se passe relativement bien et les personnages sont quelque peu humoristiques pour peu qu'on sache l'anglais, mais un fois rendu au niveau des coeurs brisés, assurez-vous de ne pas avoir d'arme à proximité (dans la vraie vie), car vous serez soudainement tentés de vous en servir! La difficulté de ce niveau est telle et on est si lourdement handicapé par les mécaniques plus que simplistes du jeu que ce niveau est infaisable et hautement frustrant. 

Essayer chaques stratégies imaginables les unes après les autres toujours en vain nous rappelle notre pareille vanité et après nous avoir élevé dans une ire divine, ce "jeu" nous ramène sur terre avec comme seuls souvenirs : un jeu incomplété et une âme peinée.

It's a great game with a charming story and mechanics, and it seemed like a walk in the park for the first 15ish minutes of my first playthrough.

Then came the Chest.

The Jealous Chest.

I decided to start up a second playthrough and went to unlock the chest's secrets, and the game goes from easy to teeth-grindingly difficult for the last 4-5 puzzles before you can get to the chest. (Protip: You can actually get to the chest without clearing all the challenges up to that point, there are 29 people that need healing and only 28 hearts are required.) After I unlocked the power upgrade, I just went from chest to chest picking up everything I could, and the game went to a relative breeze again. The only other real stopping point I had was at the other secret area in the game, which I won't spoil.

This game has content for people who are just looking to heal some people without too much hassle, and for those hardcore completionists waiting for a glorious bonus to get them through the campaign. 

9/10 and if you can run Steam, you can run this game.

34024898.review:
Princess Remedy in a World of Hurt is a cute, fun and enjoyable experience. The game is short and can be completed in about an hour (or a little sooner, or longer depending on your skill level). Best of all it's free and a great time killer.

[b]Story[/b] 7/10
[b]Characters[/b] 8.5/10
The story of Princess Remedy in a World of Hurt isn't complex or deep (which is understandable for such a short game), but it does offer fun and witty dialogue from the various "sick" NPCs you'll come across that will make you crack a smile or offer up an unexpected giggle. It is worth reading the dialogue from each character you come across as this is one of the more enjoyable aspects of the game that helps immerse yourself into Hurtworld.

[b]Art[/b] 8/10

The game offers a nostalgic feeling with its unique twist on the pixel art genre, with familiarities to character looks of older Gameboy games like Pokémon. It's interesting to look at and simple in style (also very cute). The game gives life and anthropomorphizes creatures such as flowers and chests which only increases its charm, making it feel whimsical.

There is one thing I can critique in terms of the art, is that some things can be hard to make out what they initially are, taking away a bit of the magic as you sit and try to guess what you're looking at. But this doesn't happen often and most things can be clearly understood.

[b]Music and Sounds[/b] 5/10

The music and sounds in the game are average. Not bad, but not really impressive either. Only a couple sounds stick out in my memory since I've played. This isn't an important aspect of the game and doesn't take away from my rating, as most of the fun comes from the gameplay.

[b]Gameplay[/b] 9/10

The gameplay is very fun and somewhat addicting, leaving you wanting more after you finish the game. As you heal people and come across chests you unlock hearts and power-ups to make Princess Remedy stronger and unlock various zones by doing so. It's a Bullet Hell genre and can be challenging, even on a normal difficulty for those unfamiliar with this style of combat, but it's also forgiving and a good intro to games of a similar style. One of the most interesting and fun parts of this game for me [i]personally[/i] is the secrets you can unlock and find along the way. A favorite game series of mine is The Legend of Zelda and finding those hidden chests and pathways always ignites a feeling of happiness from me. This game offers both of those aspects. There are multiple hidden chests, NPCs, and paths to search for while playing. The game also offers multiple endings and you can marry whoever (or whatever) you want!

[b]Overall[/b] 8/10

In total I average the game a 8/10, not counting the music section as it neither added or took away from my experience.

33724237.review:
Despite being a short game, I do have a little to talk about this game. Which is surprising since it’s really short. Like less than an hour short. It’s still going to be a short review but still.

Story:

You are Princess Remedy and you must travel across Hurtland to heal the Prince who is suffering from something terrible. And along you can heal people suffering from illness, confusion, stubbed toes, questioning their identity, loneliness and death to name a few.

Gameplay:

The game is top down and you have to explore areas for people who are not well. Simply talk to one of them and you have to battle what’s bothering them. You are constantly shooting you healing tool and heal when your not being hit.  In terms of the enemies, like any good game they are simple to identify and know what to do against. At first you fight simple boulders that chase you and breadcrumb mine but soon you fight bats who randomly at high speeds and slime balls that fire a volley in short burst. 
Since you only have the one attack, the only strategy is to know who can do what. One tip I can give is to explore every area you have access to before you talk to anyone as you can find chests which contain upgrades like Multi which increase the number of shots fired or Flasks which increases the number of grenades you can use per fight.
I also think I should mention the hard setting, cause it’s not just faster enemies. All of them are replaced with harder version of themselves like the breadcrumbs can charge up three shots at once and many foes that didn’t fire bullets do now. And Master(Which I didn’t do) is everything being fast.

Presentation:
The music is pretty enjoyable. Nothing that can get into your head but its some nice 8-bit tracks. I also like the simple outline graphics but that’s because I like cute stuff. I think the style they were going with was Gameboy cause it not NES and Atari graphic would be an insult to this game.

Verdict:
Although it’s so short I beat the game twice in less than two hours, I see very little, or anything wrong with it.

10/10

33455777.review:
Well, this was rather an adorable little surprise with the potential for a real game with both charm and challenge for the price of nothing—only the amount of smiles it’ll bring to you. As an avid fan of Ittle Dew, this was a lovely return to the childlike simplicity and challenge from Ludosity.

[h1]How Very NESs[/h1]

As someone who grew up in the N64/GameCube era of videogames, it’s rare for a game that harkens back to NES era graphical fidelity and gameplay simplicity to captivate me with so much nostalgia. Immediately as the game launches, the main theme puts you under its spell much like launching StarTropics with the feeling of wanting to go explore the world. What follows is a harmless adventure as you rid the land of its ills by blasting away all the suffering across the land with the healing magic of Princess Remedy. The kind of magic that involves shooting lasers, explosive flasks and dodging projectiles while your cure the ironic symptoms out of your patients. 

The gameplay is sort of a mix-up of various classic NES games; it’s a 2D shooter/bullet-hell adventure that uses the original Star Fox controls for combat of movement guiding your automated attacks with Dr. Mario’s enemy designs in battle sequences and a simplified Final Fantasy/Dragon Quest/Star Tropics overworld to explore. Each encounter feels tailored to the situation plaguing the patient with a scaling level of challenge that gets only more complicated the higher you go on the difficulty scale to Master. Eventually, it ends in a gauntlet of a final boss with multiple forms that requires you to be at your very best to beat the game. (And then you can choose who to marry from anyone you’ve met throughout the entire game to be your king/queen.)

Like its roots, Princess Remedy is a rather short game that has NES-Level Difficulty if you raise the challenge up to Master Rating as a Normal run will probably last you over three-quarters of an hour of a quality time. Whether you crave something entertainingly simple, challenging or charming, there’s something for everyone to enjoy within this offering to interest you in buying the prequel.

[h1]No Negative Nancies? What Gives? Who Are You?[/h1]

As a free game any issues I have with the gameplay itself is something I feel is mitigated by how short and to the point is Princess Remedy, and I figured any complaints I would have would better be used in the prequel as that costs money to purchase as well as being a more full experience. 

However, there are a few technical/gameplay issues that are the result of Game Maker. For starters, the game has a weird one-button limitation with various buttons to choose that can bring up the menu when you want to run or interact with someone as everything is mapped to one button. The game also has a weird technical issue where if you launch it not in safe-mode the game takes a lot longer to close as it doesn’t appear on the task manager, so you should try relaunching the game in safe-launch until it shows your Steam profile is not in a game. The screenshots are also bewilderingly screwed up to ruin any memento snapshots you’d want to savor for later, which is fine as the Print Screen Button + Paste still works with nothing lost. All of these issues are addressed in the sequel, so I feel it’s fine to mention them here in case they dissuade others from purchasing these gems.

[h1]Tippsie Is My Waifu Potion-holic[/h1]

Like the potions from Ittle Dew’s companion, there’s something magically addicting about Princess Remedy from its concoction of simplicity, goodwill and its kick that will have you hankering for more. And unlike reality, there are no hangovers from having too much of a good thing. 

Once it’s over and the magic vanishes from the realization that it’s at the end you’ll be discarded for someone else to supply his endless desire for more. Sadly, it’s the natural order and no one can sate Tip—I mean, Princess Remedy the game forever.

32295405.review:
[h1]Princess Remedy in a World of Hurt (Review)[/h1]

Every now and then I have to stop playing the games I spent $60 on with graphics that can only run on the highest quality of computers and play a free game that could run on a toaster. Somehow Princess Remedy in a World of Hurt could hold it's own against those $60 games.

[h1]Gameplay:[/h1]

Princess Remedy's gameplay is mainly found in the combat, which plays like a bullet-hell, with a bit of puzzles mixed into the mix.

You fight a cast of enemies who vary depending on the person you are healing, each with their own strategy and weakness.

The fights get more difficult as you get more powerful.

It's simple, but it works.

What I liked the most was that losing meant nothing! Every time you fail to cure someone you can just try again! This doesn't work well for every game, but it works well here.

[h1]Story:[/h1]

The story in Princess Remedy is as generic as it gets and is basically all put out on the table for you before you even get to play.

You go on a quest to save a princess...

Except he's a prince...

And you use the power of modern medicine...

Fabulous.

Along the way you unlock the next areas with "hearts". "Hearts" are earned by helping out people with their troubles, which is where the real story comes in.

You find people troubled by all sorts of ailments and most of them are hilarious.

You'll find a slime who only smells a little, a flower who needs confidence to tell a tree to get out of his way so he can get sunlight, and a man who's face melted after getting to close to the sun.

This game genuinely made me laugh, multiple times, which cannot be said of many games.

I won't spoil the ending, but it also leads to many hilarious moments.

I will say though, the game's ending revealed how much of the game you beat. I was informed I had only completed 97% and, after wandering aimlessly for another 10 minutes, couldn't find any of the hearts I was missing... 

Other than that the only real problem I had with the story was the length! I finished this game in just over an hour!

[h1]Graphics:[/h1]

The graphics are charming. Everything about them screams "old school".

At one point in time I tried to learn how to create pixel art. I was told it was the art of creating beauty through limitations. This game takes it's limitations and makes it it's strength.

From the enemies, to the overworld, to your attacks, everything is simplistic yet dazzling.

My favorite bit of pixel art are the attacks made by Princess Remedy. Her attacks start off as band-aids, then pills, shots, and eventually sparkles, each wonderfully animated. 

[h1]Soundtrack:[/h1]

I played this game talking with a friend who was also playing Princess Remedy and one of our favorite parts was the music.

From the moment you hit the title screen to the second you beat the game, you are in for a great time. The music is spot on and matches the theme of each level perfectly.

You can listen to the soundtrack [url=https://soundcloud.com/dothaku/sets/princess-remedy-in-a-world-of-hurt]here[/url]. My favorite track was [url=https://soundcloud.com/dothaku/rising-hero?in=dothaku/sets/princess-remedy-in-a-world-of-hurt]Rising Hero[/url], which will probably be my next ringtone. 

[h1]Replay Value:[/h1]

There are multiple different difficulty settings and easter eggs to find, which makes the replay value decent, but unless you feel like playing the game multiple times, which isn't a problem considering it can be beaten in about an hour, there isn't much to do.

[h1]Other Recommendations:[/h1]

The obvious recommendation is Undertale.

From the very begging you can see the signs. The art style, the bullet-hell gameplay, and the lovable, funny characters. Some say that this was full on copying, but I don't stand on that side of the argument.

Other than that, not much comes to mind, but it does have a sequel, which might be worth a look.

[h1]Pricing:[/h1]

Ah, yes. The icing on the cake.

It's free.

Now, hold on. I will say that I don't like free games getting a pass because thy're free. I've played MANY terrible  free games, but thankfully this one does not fall into that category.

This game is a bit of a hidden gem, most likely because of the fact that it's free. I personally put this game off for a good while before playing it because I knew people might just be saying it's good because it's free when it might just be alright.

Trust me, this game is great and totally worth your time for the price of free.

[h1]Final Thoughts:[/h1]

A fun, retro-style, bullet-hell with RPG elements that I would recommend to anyone for the price of free!

[h1]9/10[/h1]

Thanks for reading! Please, support my work by joining [url=http://steamcommunity.com/groups/droppablereviews]my group[/url], inviting friends, commenting below, and maybe even sending me something cool! As always, this is DropTheChair dropping another great review from Droppable Reviews!

31534822.review: Beautiful music, adorable art which digs deeper into time than the typical Famicom/DOS era pixel art that is common today (not that there's anything wrong with that) and creates an adorable style with simplistic colors and black dominating the screen, a fun bullet hell that never becomes frustrating, and a brisk progression to the end... This game is free to play? It takes an hour of time to beat your first go around? Why hasn't everyone on my friends list tried this? Princess Remedy is a truly precious story that is lightly silly and engaging throughout with a wonderful note of poignance at its climax and a simply satisfying conclusion. I've beaten this game for the first time recently and am halfway through its (cheaply purchasable sequel!) and I can't recommend this enough to whoever might be reading my reviews.

30946598.review:
Absolute delight of a game.

Would pay up to £4 for.

It's short and sweet, yet weirdly doesn't need to be anything more than it is.

The whole thing is controlled by basic direction keys and a single action key that acts to open the menu, sprint, interact, or throw flasks ("grenades") depending on the context of its use. 5 buttons total.

There's an Apathetic Frog who entirely lives up to its name.

Some of the battles ("healing mode") offer a decent challenge; the game itself not punishing the player for failing a battle, at least on the normal difficulty setting.

One mechanic sees flasks only deducted from your inventory if you succeed in that particular battle scenario, ensuring you never feel that they are wasted given their limited number in the game. A defeat returning you to before the battle commenced (Again, at least on normal difficulty. I can't speak for the higher difficulties, yet).

I am really fond of this game. I've seen it on my storefront for a while and played it only because I was stuck on a crappy laptop for an afternoon.

I'm glad I did play Princess Remedy and I think most people would be glad to have played it too.

I mean, go on, why not... it's FREE.

30484861.review:
Princess Remedy in a World of Hurt is the story of a selfless healer's whimsical adventure through Hurtland, a place where everyone and their dog suffers from maladies ranging from the plague to hypochondria. Your job as Princess Remedy, physician extraordinaire, is to cure afflictions by navigating screens full of baddies and auto-firing them into oblivion while tossing healing flasks and avoiding damage.

The gameplay is a turbo-drive romp through pixellated forests and towns with intentionally limited color depth; the music uses every one of its eight bits to rock out to the tune of your superstar curing prowess. Your projectiles transform and multiply as you become more efficient at healing, while your hearts and regeneration increase, allowing you to take more hits from nasty germs and carcinogens.

Serious business goes out the window straight away: a jealous chest won't let you open it if you've opened other chests before it but will still accept your hand in marriage; NPCs are given colorful names such as "Some Girl" and "Moonbunny"; and years of estrangement can be righted in one fell swoop with a box of chocolates. Who need reality, anyways?

A disproportionately high number of levels can be defeated by simply standing still which is offset by the moderate level of Bullet Heck present in some of the more challenging screens. It's nothing repeated attempts won't smash down, however, and that's one of the attractive features of this relatively short game: pressing buttons until you win.

Overall, I'd recommend it to anyone looking for a quick bit of fast-paced fun.

30463896.review:
Princess Remedy in a World of Hurt Review - Raymond KT

Summary: Remedy, a recent graduate from the Saturnian healing school, must descend to Hurtland and use her powers to heal everyone from stray ducks to dark lords, and finally cure the ailing Prince Hingst. It's a short, whimsical adventure with plenty of heart(s).

This game was one of Ludosity's entries in the Games Against Ebola charity game jam, made in four days of livestreamed development. Anton made the graphics, Mattias and Stefan made the music, and I did the rest. This version was made after the jam to include options, multiple savefiles, more difficulty levels, and gamepad support.

I'm not one for bullet hell games, but I was drawn in by the unique graphics. It took me a little over an hour to complete due to some difficulty with certain encounters, but the game is very forgiving in that you can immediately jump back into a fight time after time. Starts off with easy battles and progresses into more difficult enemy setups. Little to no actual story, but you can marry anyone you want. I recommend this game if you have some time to kill but don't feel like playing anything too in-depth

30461577.review: An adorably cute retro-style game with a rockin' 8-bit soundtrack of a princess as she travels through Hurtland, healing everyone she comes across. It's a game that's full of charm with its quirky dialogue and keeps itself going with its simple, yet engaging gameplay mechanics that makes it [i] almost	[/i] a bullethell with some RPG elements. I would recommend this game to anyone just looking for something to play, particularly to those who know they'll enjoy this sort of retro-throwback aesthetic. Plus, the game is free and it can be beaten in less than two hours! What do you have to lose? Would recommend.

30150881.review:
Razões para jogar Princess Remedy in a World of Hurt:

Esse é um jogo do estilo Bullet Hell com um sistema de escolha de mundos e fases mascarado de RPG's dos anos 80-90. A quase inocente ambientação e o sistema de status que progride de forma totalmente passiva escondem a agitação dificuldade de os momentos de combate trazem, o que faz maravilha com o pacing do jogo. Bela forma de trabalhar com conceitos e estilos contrastantes em um jogo.

O gameplay é bastante sólido, responsivo e traz um level design de qualidade surpreendente! Não costumo jogar jogos nesse estilo, mas PRiaWoH trouxe a melhor apresentação de mecânicas entre os que eu já joguei, honestamente. 

Por último mas definitivamente não menos importante, o jogo é gratuito! Isso reduz muito o risco de jogá-lo por conta de uma recomendação de um maluco qualquer. Me fez refletir também sobre uma nova forma de se vender como desenvolvedor de jogos. Não há melhor forma de mostrar que entende de game design do que por meio de um jogo que traz em diversão o que lhe falta em polimento.  

Então se gostar de jogos estilo bullet hell com um conceito bastante único, um level design de qualidade e que não lhe custará um tustão para testá-lo, Princess Remedy in a World of Hurt é o jogo pra você!

I just got this game out of curiousity, and... well, here's a short way to describe it.
"Prince is sick, go heal him." An RPG plot doesn't get more simple than that.

Overall, the 8-bit soundtrack and graphics goes well with the game itself, which looks like it could perfectly fit on the NES as an earlier title. Another great part about this game is the fact that there are so many secrets hidden within the game, but I won't tell you. You'll have to find them out yourself. Then there's Healing Mode. Oh boy. Healing Mode. If you don't know how an enemy attacks, you may fail on the first try. Overall, it does get easier. If you can't beat something, go find some gear and then get back to it. But if you still can't beat, then I don't know what to tell you. Just play another game.

Princess Remedy in a World of Hurt is short, simple, a bit difficult, but real fun to play.

*Edit (since many people are irritated why I don't recommend it)*:
The problem with the recommendations on steam is that they are given by many people for mediocre games. I only recommend games, I want other people to take note on. That's what recommendation means. It doesn't mean "it's was an ok game, I felt entertained for a bit, but I will never think about this game again, nor feel the wish to talk to anybody about my experience with this game." The price tag does matter, but that doesn't mean every free game is worth a recommendation. A thumbs down doesn't necessarily mean it's a bad game, for me it only means it's not in the circle of games worth recommending. At least that is how I interpret Steam's binary voting system....

29478589.review: I highly recommend this game, it is super cute, short, and sweet (free to play as well). the game itself is simple, you go around the world as Princess Remedy and heal the various denizens of the game of their "ailments".  it has a gameboy look and feel to it, with a certain Dr.Mario vibe without the puzzles, the battles take place by simply speaking to the sick characters and engaging in a bullet hell like auto-shooter where you defeat their illnesses manifested as different monsters. The game also has a very self aware sense of humor with plenty of references to other older games, the progression is simple enough you collect hearts to unlock gates leading to each section of the game. it'll take anyone about 30 -45 minutes to complete the entire game, and if for all the completionists out there it might take 2 runs to get every upgrade and chest. The final boss alone is worth every minute of the game, it is completely hilarious, I'm not going to spoil it but any final fantasy fan should get the reference right off the bat. all in all a super cute, highly original free to play game. play it, you cannot go wrong.

29242628.review:
[i]Princess Remedy in a World of Hurt[/i] is a short experience, but thought has been put in to every moment of that experience, and it shows. It's a simple bullet-hell game with fast paced levels that take advantage of a constrained playing field to present interesting and varied challenges. The mechanics are just deep enough that I felt like I was learning something new through almost every part of my 45 minute playthrough, but I wouldn't recommend it solely on the virtues of its gameplay. [i]Princess Remedy[/i] is fun in a large part because of how charming it is. The dialogue is humorous, the music and art are reminiscent of the Atari 2600 (but in a good way), and the entire game just oozes goodness and joy in a way that seems authentic instead of saccharine. Well worth the time it took to play, and I'd recommend it to anyone with a spare hour.

Pros:
•	Tight gameplay
•	Actually good retro pixel art
•	Funny dialogue
•	The price tag (it's free!)

Cons:
•	Character upgrade system not particularly deep
•	Maybe too short for some people's taste

29136662.review:
Princess Remedy c'est une lettre d'amour rédigée à l'intention de la console Game Boy. Ce jeu résonnera avec davantage de force dans l'esprit de ceux qui ont bien connu les JRPG monochromes de cette époque et principalement la trilogie Sa•Ga (Final Fantasy Legend en version U.S.).

Mais résumer ce jeu à une vague exploitation de la nostalgie de ceux qui ont connu les prémisses des jeux vidéo d'aujourd'hui serait une erreur. Princess Remedy est une petite perle de game design. D'une simplicité confondante et d'une économie de moyen sans pareil, ce jeu parvient tout de même à nous proposer une progression entrainante, agrémenter d'une ambiance musicale tout à fait d'époque, et cela tout au long de sa courte durée de vie. Mais jugez plutôt :

Que ce soit la partie exploration du jeu où l'on débloque les accès par le biais de serrures nécessitant un nombre précis de clés pour être ouvertes ou que ce soit la partie combat où l'on peut voir notre héroïne acquérir petit à petit un arsenal de défense au moins aussi impressionnant que celui des légendaires shoot them up japonais (Slap Fight, do you remember ?), le jeu nous pousse toujours à aller de l'avant jusqu'à nous faire regretter d'en voir si rapidement la fin.

Alors oui, Princess Remedy est gratuit, et aussi oui, ça joue sans doute sur le plaisir que j'ai eu à le terminer et le peu de risques que je prends à vous le conseiller sans détour. Mais voilà, en jouant à ce jeu vous pourrez tenter d'approcher ce que ressentaient les personnes qui comme moi jouaient sans relâche à la Game Boy à son heure de gloire, mais aussi, si vous parvenez à prendre du plaisir avec ce jeu, vous saurez désormais que toute un univers de petites perles pas toujours très connues n'attendent que vous sur la portable désuète de Nintendo.

Éh oui, le passé a plus d'avenir qu'on ne le pense, surtout dans l'univers du jeu vidéo où hier et aujourd'hui semblent s'entremêler et s'influencer sans cesse pour nous faire voyager toujours plus loin. Alors n'oubliez pas, vous n'êtes pas Orphée, vous ne risquez rien à regardez en arrière, bien au contraire même. Bon retour.

28734255.review: Princess Remedy is a cute little game where you play through bullet hell levels trying to get people cured from a wide range of ailments. It's remarkably simple. You only have one action button, and might just as well play this with an Atari joystick. While this can be troubling at times, it makes for a very distinct gameplay. Just move around and try to hit the enemies without being killed. In the Hard and Master difficulty levels, you'll probably spend more time dodging bullets and just hoping you hit something. 28718447.review:
[h1] A Loving Tribute to 8-bit Gaming [/h1]

A short and sweet game. I finished it in one sitting. It has enough variety in its enemies to keep your interest going, and the powerup progress and map layout have been designed such that you don't have to grind much or wander around needlessly. The controls are minimal, and pleasantly so. The combat, "healing" segments feature simple action that gradually turns into bullet hell action later on. The story's very light, held together by cute one-liners. As for the music, and the graphics: well, [i] the nostalgia is strong with this one. [/i]

Playing this was some of the most fun I've had recently with games. Someone earlier wrote in a review that, had this been released in the heyday of the NES, it would have been a classic. One may argue the point, but I'm sure of one thing... there would have been a long line of sequels, spanning later consoles like the SNES and maybe the N64. Perhaps even an animated TV show.

I love the irreverent humor in this game. Where else can you marry whomever you want? If it had indeed been released in the 80s, the social mayhem would have been a sight to behold! (And this would not have been in the TV show.)

27791128.review: A warmhearted, endearing and very surreal trip.  One of those rare games that brightens your day.  Has its own quirky style of humor.  Remedy is a princess set out not to fight monsters but to save others by ridding them of the enemy within themselves.  Its presented as a minimalist rpg and some exploration.  The side shooter healing "battles" are enough for a challenge but never so much that you will be frustrated, and the game gives you unlimited retries.  Those who want a challenge can select a higher difficulty mode.  Combined with a simple 2d retro but still pretty art style that shouldn't be a reason to overlook this.  As for the music, it fits so well and is definitely memorable.  A bit short but worth every minute.  You'll be hooked within the first 5 minutes of trying it.  It might be free but it would definitely be worth paying for.

8-bit, 그 중에서도 마치 슈퍼패미컴세대보다 더 오래된 듯한 고전의 향수를 제대로 담아놓은 치료를 빙자한 슈팅RPG겜입니다.

컨트롤 겜에 자신 있으신 분들이라면 이 겜을 제대로 즐기기 위해 마스터 난이도를 꼭 하시길 추천드립니다.
사실 마스터보다 한 단계 높은 난이도가 더 있지만... 그건 작정하고 플레이 불가로 만든 이스터 에그니 넘어갑시다
마스터 모드에서 황금 상자를 까기 위해서 컨트롤 뿐만 아니라 폭탄을 어떻게 사용해야 하는지
어떤 병균을 먼저 없애야 할지 장애물은 어떻게 처리해야 할지 등등의 
전략적인 판단을 해야만 했던 것이 가장 빡셌지만 재미있었다고 생각합니다.

시대에 뒤떨어진 그래픽, 사운드를 혐오하시는 분들에겐 굳이 추천하고 싶지 않지만

27624986.review: Here's a sweet little jazz single for you. It looks like a Spectrum game, feels like a Game Boy game, and has the spirit of a MegaZeux game, and yet it's totally modern Indie. The writing is cute, there's only one action button, the enemies burst beautifully, and everything you find leads to a level-up. 27234407.review:
Princess Remedy takes a lot of the things we love about RPGs, throws out the things we hate about them, and does an excellent job of making a fun and engaging experience. The thing that I love the most is that you can jump right in and play. Many RPGs have a long expositional introduction that can last an hour or maybe even two hours (lookin' at you, Kingdom Hearts II...) just giving you back story and teaching you the mechanics. Princess Remedy teaches the mechanics and story in mere seconds and then throws you into the world to start playing and exploring. The entire game can be beaten in an hour. Combine a simple RPG with Bullet-Hell/Shooter combat and you've got a fresh and fun experience. Did I mention it's free?! 

+Super Cute
+Short and Sweet
+Retro Graphics
+Excellent, Energetic Soundtrack
+Fun Combat
+FREE!

10/10

27157283.review:
You can finish this game with 100% completion (all upgrades/"items" found) in under an hour, so there's no large time-sink involved in giving this game a go. Essentially, the entirety of the game consists of going into 2D battles where you shoot at diseases that try to touch or shoot you, and killing them gives you hearts. You then unlock new areas by having a certain number of hearts, Mario 64-stars-style, all while looking for funny-looking clues like an X on an edge tile to tell you there's a wall you can walk through for secret areas, and opening chests containing hearts upgrades for your character, such as stronger firepower, additional shots/spread per attack, extra flasks (grenades), better health regen, etc.

This game is quick, fun, and free. I definitely recommend giving it a go. I enjoyed it, and you can't beat the "price."

26880348.review:
TLDR - Old school fun in the best kind of way (ALSO IT'S FREAKING FREE).
...

The game in its normal mode is only about an hour long, but it's a challenging little romp.  Going for 101% completion adds some time to that.

Playing the game on MAX DIFFICULTY is the same "hurts so good" (no pun intended), flying on a wing and a prayer adrenaline rush that I get from Dark Souls.  It's not impossible, but hoo boy is it a ride!

The throwback graphics hit a sweet spot between an advanced Atari 2600 game and a primative NES game.  It's super charming and the graphical "errors" are clearly an homage to those early days.  I also like the choice not to make this a twin stick shooter and to keep the controls as simple as directional input and a single button for interaction or special attacks for just a little more of that old school flavor!

There's some witty humor to be found in the dialogue, but the game's real personality SHINES in the music.  This baby is filled with expertly crafted tunes you're sure to get stuck in your head.

I can't reccomend this game enough.  It's super short on normal mode, but that's okay - it's free!  Max difficulty will have you howling with savage pride each time you beat a level you get stuck on.  

Play it, love it, tell a friend.

26728294.review:
I jumped into this game blindly, streaming it for a few friends late at night. It was probably one of the most comfortable but challenging games I had played in some time. The graphics and music are so charming and excellent in matching the aesthetic where most "retro" games will be a mishmash of 16/32-bit graphics and call it "8-bit". This game comes at you with challenging bullet-hell mechanics in similar vein to The Binding of Isaac and Undertale. Playing through the first run on Normal Mode I got through without too much trouble at all. The second run I did immediately after I did on Hard Mode. I wasn't sure if it was my own exhaustion of playing this game at 2-3AM or the sheer difficulty alone but I found myself gritting my teeth and struggling to defeat the waves of diverse enemies and master dancing around their hectic movement and fiting patterns. Come the end of the stream I had come out of the ordeal a much more accomplished feeling and generally happier person.

If you're looking for a hidden gem or something fun you can run in an hour or two and love games like The Binding of Isaac, Undertale or generally adorable and engrossingly challenging old-school games. This game is a must. If you haven't played it yet, you're missing out on one of the few Free Games on Steam that's worth your time and much more. Not having the reviewer bias of having the game given to me for free since it already is free, I will DEFINITELY be buying  the sequel to this as soon as I can. Eager to see what is in store for me.

26698469.review:
Princess Remedy in a World of Hurt é um jogo indie com gráficos bem retrôs 8bits do gênero Action/RPG/Adventure. 

Você toma controle da Princessa Remédio, uma aluna recém-formada em uma Academia onde as garotas aprendem curar, e que tem a missão de curar o Príncipe que está muito doente assim como todo o seu reino.

A jogabilidade é separada por 2 partes: A primeira quando você anda normalmente pelo mapa, um RPG, obtendo elementos para melhorar sua personagem. Assim ao encontrar alguém doente, você troca para um sistema de shooter~action (semelhante a The Binding of Isaac) no qual você tem que derrotar os inimigos usando bandagens, seringas etc, assim como desviar dos tiros no timing certo.

Ele é curto sim de fato, zerei a primeira vez em 40 minutos e a segunda vez em 35 minutos (obtendo o 100%), mas de graça e criado como forma de caridade, Princess Remedy in a World of Hurt tem uma atmosfera extremamente nostálgica e divertida, o jogo é excelente e de graça, recomendo a todos darem ao menos uma boa conferida.  Curto, gostoso, 8-bits e bem hilário (a começar pelo título). Poderia ser pago que eu ainda recomendaria.

26343318.review: This was an enjoyable romp.  I beat the entire game in only an hour, but I enjoyed the time doing so.  The graphics are very simplistic, but I'm glad to see the pictures actually representing objects and people instead of geometric shapes the way some games have gone with oversimplifying the graphics.  This obviously isn't the reason you play the game though.  It's for the very quirky humor it employs as you explore the land in RPG style and battle the infections in a mix of Bomber Man and arcade shooter style.  Each battle consists of a basic configuration of enemies and possibly breakable blocks designed for various challenge levels.  They are over quickly, which is good as you aren't really punished for failing and can retry quickly until you get it.  I didn't really care about the multiple ending aspect, but I will give credit where it's due, as that is a high degree of versatility and effort to put in when they certainly didn't need to.  It also allows for more humor for someone who might have a personal favorite NPC they want to check on this way.  All in all it's a very nice game that does what games are supposed to.  Be fun to play.

Princess Remedy is a bullet hell rpg with very minimal mechanics, story, and game play. Healing your way through friends and foes alike will be the premise in this games story. Overall, if you have a hour to burn and don't mind the occasional FTP shoot me up, then give it a go. Keep in mind this game isn't very difficult, so bump the difficulty to Hard or more.

Pros

-Free
-Cute retro art style
-Sudo fun game

Cons

-Short (Little over a hour on hard)
-No Options menu for keybindings
-Dialog and run key are both bound as an action key. Can get annoying

Overall I would recommend this game. It's short, mildly fun, and will pass that time for when your done with one game and waiting for that next game idea to come to mind.

This guy used to make amazing shootemups all the way back on yoyogames.com when it was a sandbox and not just a platform to sell around 20 or 30 games, plus its game designer software. And he gave them out FOR FREE.

I am elated to see he continues this practice here on Steam, and while Princess Remedy is not quite as expansive as his other projects, the quality is still on-point with the standard I've come to expect from Remar Games.

And while he is selling an expansion to this game for money, I bear no resentment. The man puts out quality stuff, and it's impressive enough he gives out a game like this for nothing at all. 26045267.review:
Quick blurb: It's free, it's short, it's cute as hell, it's a lot of fun. Give it a shot.

As for the lengthier version, this game emulates the ZX Spectrum game visuals of the 80s and early 90s. Empty black backdrop with bright coloured simple sprites, then plays like a zelda-esque shootemup in the combat minigame segments.

Heal the denizens of Hurtworld (both humanoid and not, and both mundane and completely bizarre, in often amusing ways), by shooting representations of their troubles with medical equipment, to progress further until you meet the prince (or was it king?) of Hurtland, and heal them too. Then get married to anybody you like.

I do mean anybody. anyone you've talked to.

anyTHING you've talked to for that matter.

There's very little story here, it's just a silly, fun romp for all of about an hour, and it's completely free, and you absolutely should give it a shot because A) it's free, B) sunglasses, C) it's cute as hell and surprisingly fun and D) it's genuinely charming and funny.

You seriously have nothing to lose, and everything to gain from a daft little gamejam thing that costs you nothing but an hour of your time. Get some healing done.

Also there's a paid for sequel that expands on the game and is also very cheap and you may wanna check that out too.

25945624.review:
This game is a short story about Princess Remedy who has a quest to cure the Prince of Hurtland.
However, in order to reach him along the way you will need to heal other people aswell.

Game itself is very simple, besides traveling through villages, you will have to heal other people in order to unlock the hearts which will let you progress through the story, and which will also increase your healing stats. 
Healing is a minigame, very similiar to Undertale the Bullet Storm style, while throwing bandages and painkillers at enemies, you will also have to run away from enemies and dodge their attacks. 

Besides that there isnt much, finding secret chests with upgrades and hearing interesting stories and illnesses from other people in Hurtland.


Even though its very simple and short, i did acctualy enjoy the game. It takes around 1-2 hours to finish.

Pros:
- Short, unusual story
- Low system requirements and small download size
- Over 50 different characters, each with unique illness, healing level and story about it
- Customizable difficulty (Normal, Hard, Master)
- Music is pretty nice
- Secret rooms and collectible upgrades
- 3 save files

Neutral:
- Graphics probably wont appeal to everyone, however they do give special charm to game, and it looks and sounds like something you would play on Gameboy
- Short and simple, some people like diversity
- No equipment nor money, only thing you collect are the keys for doors and upgrades from chests and cured characters instead of collecting money/equipment. Every upgrade is direct non customizable upgrade, that means you cant lower your stats if for some reason you want to (f.e if you want harder challenge at some parts of the game)

Cons:
- 30 FPS cap
- No achievements
- It seems like some healing levels are either alot harder or alot easier for the part of the game (town) they are in, it starts somewhere in midgame
- Alot of flashing lights, can cause headache if you play with Fullscreen
- Maybe could use a little bit of customization for character, couple of outfits or something, but its not a big deal

25880082.review:
Ludosity games always seem to have one or two issues that ruins their games for me. Whether it was the lack of significant meaningful choice in deckbuilding in Card City Nights or providing not quite enough information to the player in PsyCard* leading to a lot of feeling like success or failure came down to random chance. Luckily, Daniel Remar had his hand in this particular stew so I  dove right in.

First off, I love the graphic style of this game. The 2-color 16x16 tiled canvas has some amazing pixel work to create a vibrant world where everything is nicely readable and with the sort of visual acuity that makes it easy to navigate. 

In general, the gameplay is pretty good, you travel the land seeking out people who are suffering from various maladies and 'cure' them by taking part in a single-screen arena shooter match. It plays out sort of like a twin-stick shooter like Robotron or Smash TV, except for the part where there's a second stick, and that's where Princess Remedy sort of falls apart. It's not terrible, you only can shoot in the direction you're facing, but it adds a layer of challenge that's not really needed for this style of gameplay. And it's not that the various stages are really all that difficult outside of Master difficulty doing no-chests up to the secret chest, and then again at the last boss doing 101%.

The point is it just feels bad, even an old game like Robotron knew you needed to be able to control your gun independantly of your character! The hitbox on Remedy also feels off, which again for the vast majority of gameplay isn't really an issue, but she's a chunky sprite and there are times when it seems like she can squeeze between certain bullet patterns and other times when she gets hit. There not a good feeling of how many invincibility frames (if any) you get after being hit too, and sometimes bullets seem to do wildly different amounts of damage, though I suspect there's a bit of either overlapping bullets happening or some bullets are just allowed to hit the player more than once. Whichever it is, it's really too bad because it turns the game from feeling challenging to just feeling arbitrary.

Again, this is really only important at the highest difficulty the game provides. All in all, these issues don't completely spoil the game and I would certainly recommend Princess Remedy to anyone looking for a fun little game with tons of style. And I'm certainly looking forward to trying the sequel.

*While I can't really recommend this game, there's a super fun dungeon crawer style minigame that comes with it that's really fun and it's almost baffling they didn't make that into a full fledged game experience.

25863216.review:
A fun little game worth your time, but not without its flaws. Princess Remedy is a tight experience with simplistic gameplay and great presentation, with beautiful retro graphics, a good soundtrack, and funny dialogue. I played on hard mode once and got 99% completion, but could still see myself giving it another go in the future due to its plethora of endings.

Pros:
[list]
    [*]Fairly good art and sound design
    [*]Dialogue with humor that very rarely falls flat
    [*]Modest replayability between countless secrets (even if most are easily found) and a plethora of endings (albeit their differences are only slight)
[/list]

Cons:
list]
    [*]Combat is nothing you haven't seen before, and lacks many of the innovations we expect in a modern top-down shooter. For instance, you can only fire in the direction you are moving. However, the game is crafted around this, and it succeeds in emulating older games.
    [*]A minor gripe, but some enemies are unidentifiable, or nonsensical. This doesn't impact gameplay, but somewhat contrasts with how easily identifiable most other things are.
[/list]

Over all, I'd recommend giving it a go if you've got time on your hands. The creator was smart making this free to play, because I'm geniuenly considering getting the sequel when normally I'd skip right past it had I just seen it on the store page.

25788265.review:
This is a cute little game with NES / late Atarish graphics that I polished off in under an hour while waiting for my buddy to put together a Pathfinder character. 

It's free, which is obviously a plus, and it has a very cute, albeit it not uproariously funny sense of humor about it. Still enough to make me smile. You're healing people by destroying various representations of what's wrong with them, which takes the form of a bullet-helly sort of shooter. Ends with a bizarre multi-stage boss fight. 

Other than the very short length, the only real detractor is the control scheme. You can WASD or arrow key around, and escape is the "cancel out of menu" button, and literally every other button is the action button. Pressing these will enter a menu, select things within the menu, and pressing and holding it while pressing one of the directional keys will make you run. This means that often I'd be trying to run, but press the buttons out of sequence by a split second and end up nearly saving and quitting. It's a short game and not a huge deal, but it was a pain, and as feedback for the dev for future titles, I would advise against this hyper-simplified control scheme. My recommendation would be to have one rebindable button for action, one rebindable button for cancel, and one rebindable button for run. In that order I'd recommend x, z, and shift.

6/10 (5 being average, above being actively good, below being actively bad), cute and fun but nothing super special. (I feel like this was made for a game jam, and I'm judging by the virtues of your average game, so take that for what you will.)

25722923.review:
Game completed in Hard Mode.

Princess Remedy in a World of Hurt is a short, fun bullet hell game for anyone looking for a quick introduction into the genre. As Princess Remedy, your goal is to heal everyone in Hurtland, as is in the title. While you do require a specific number of Hearts to clear the game, I would search for more people in need of my help just to read their interesting two-liners.

In Healing Mode, the battle screen for the game, controls are simple, move around avoiding enemy bullets while Remedy fires her healing bullets (automatic). Pressing any main key fires a vial/bomb which deals damage to an area, useful for if you feel over-encumbered by foes. 

Death is not punishing as you can immediately challenge the stage again if you fail. No need for the hassle of looking at the main screen over and again.The game time can span from 1~2 hours, depending on your play style.

Have fun.

25404466.review:
The fundamental combat mechanic of the game is broken.

Combat is a Binding of Isaac style top down bullet hell. You would expect for it to play as a two-stick shooter.

The problem is you don't control the direction of your shots. You shoot in the direction you're facing, and you face the direction you last moved. Additionally, while you can move diagonally, you can only face in the four cardinal directions. It's anyone's guess which direction you'll end up facing as you move diagonally.

All this means that if enemies/attacks are coming at you, and they will be, your only options are to dodge and have your own attacks miss or to run right into their attacks.

25074328.review:
This is a relatively short RPG/Shoot-em up/Bullet Hell sorta hybrid with a Gameboy aesthetic that's similar to games like Undertale that play with genre-bending. While not as in depth as Undertale takes it's narrative, gameplay and morality system, it still feels as fun to play, boasts a great soundtrack and offers one heck of a good time! 

    Starting with three difficulty options, Princess Remedy leaps from Saturn(?) and safely lands in A World of Hurt. In this world almost everyone is ill and Princes Remedy is the only one who possesses the cure. Enter “Healing Mode” after talking to a disease stricken NPC and get ready for some action! Ms. Remedy only shoots forward, which happens automatically. She just shoots nonstop. It's kinda funny. She's also equipped with healing flasks that act as grenades when pressing the action button. Don't worry, the action button is every button on the controller.
 
   The shoot-em up segments ramp up in difficulty at a smooth pace and the game never feels too difficult out of nowhere. When you find a segment to be too difficult, just try helping someone else. Each time you finish curing someone, you are granted more hearts, or health, to help you on your journey. In addition to completing healing modes, you can find chests throughout the game that give you other stat boosting goodies.
 
    Remember, it's free. Totally free and clocking in just under two hours for me on normal difficulty, you're not going to loose much. The soundtrack pulled me right in and once the gameplay picked up I couldn't put the controller down. The challenge made me want to keep trying to continue, but never became too difficult to make me stop. I had such a good time I've started a second playthrough on a higher difficulty setting. I'm not bashful to say that I fell in love with this game. I want to recommend this to anybody, but maybe it will only appeal to hardcore players. I don't think so and I urge everyone to give this one a shot because it's motherfuckin' FREE, son!

24965001.review:
Magnificent freeware.

An rpg centered around healing. A bullet-hell with character progression and hp regeneration, allowing you to come back from perilous near-defeats. A dating sim, apparently, tucked in the final five minutes of play and with more emotional punch than I was prepared for in something that looks like it was designed for the Atari. 

Remedy will surprise the hell out of you, change your steam font, re-adjust your monitor settings, and generally act so politely about the whole thing that you'll forgive it quickly, if grudgingly. 

If this had been around in the Windows 3.1 days, it would be a feature in many happy childhoods. As it is, it's a pleasant little throwback and a nice way to spend an hour or so, provided the garish graphics don't immediately break your eyes.

24819146.review:
I remember when Daniel Remar made Iji and it was quite the surprise to see his name again in the ending. A pleasant surprise, mind you; I loved Iji and everything that came with it. But we're not talking about Iji; we're talking about Princess Remedy.

Visually, the game's hideous, and this is coming from someone who loves Undertale. Unlike Undertale, the visuals don't really serve the game's tone more than anything even slightly more advanced. 

Game's short but, being free, I'm not going to fault it for that. And for being only an our long, it's a fine hour. It's got the bare bones of personality and charm and that's all it really needs to pull you through. Final boss was quite the shocker, too, if kind of anticlimactic since so many enemies have killed me many times over by that point.

So yeah; if you have an hour to spare, give the game a go. You may like it, you may not, but it's worth the effort.

24726029.review:
I have to say that overall this game is extremely refreshing. A lot of people have been comparing it to Undertale and I can see why. I can't think of a line that I didn't enjoy, the characters had really cute designs, and while the game has fights where it can be really difficult/annoying it never really gets to the point of the Undyne and Sans genocide fights where some people can just drop the game because they've been trying to beat it for so long and just can't. The story is as cute as the characters and it fits really well with how short the game is. A normal run takes about an hour to complete (at least for me, but I got adjusted to the always shooting mechanic really quickly) and only a little bit longer if you're going for the special normal run. I was listening to my own music for the most part but for the moments when I was listening to the music it really fit the aesthetic of the game. 

Misc. good things:
A protagonist that isn't straight but it isn't like a huge deal or anything.
So many endings (none that really affect that much, it just gives certain characters a few extra lines. So no one should really feel that pressured to get every ending like someone that is playing a game like Undertale might be).
Humor that can range from witty to really stupid but is lovable either way. 
There was really only one fight that I found annoying but it was clear that it was one that was supposed to be difficult (and no it wasn't the final boss).
I'm not a parent or anything but I can see this being a really good game to play with kids (as far as I can remember there isn't any dirty jokes or anything so if you're someone that worries about that kind of stuff this game is good to go). 

Misc. bad things:
I can't really think of that much??
I imagine some people won't enjoy the graphics or music.
I can also see the colors getting a little straining if you're struggling with certain fights or trying to find something.
Some people wouldn't find some things funny or cute or anything (the biggest one I can think of is the character sprite being on just like a black square that moves around. Personally I found it really cute/charming, but I know some people that found it irritating/annoying).

But yeah, overall I would recommend this game. Some people just aren't going to enjoy this game and I totally get that. But as far as I can tell a lot of people are going to love it.

24644707.review:
A short but somewhat challenging game. Fans of [i]Undertale[/i] will appreciate the game's sense of humor, and its gameplay is similar. For players familiar with the bullet hell genre, [i]Princess Remedy in a World of Hurt[/i] will be quite easy. A warm up exercise, maybe. But for the casual gamer, this is a fun hour or two. Your time with the game will go by fast regardless.

Despite this, I don't wish the game was any longer. Hidden upgrades to look for and the multitude of short dialogues you can get for the game's ending were a nice addition that could take away some of the monotony from replays.

In addition, this game has more variety and complexity in its types of enemies than some triple-A titles I've played this year, with undoubtedly less code than said big budget titles. Another refreshing difference is that the game barely holds your hand. Only your controls are explained, involving a single button's functions, and the four directions. The player heads out into the world and just starts playing. Despite having not informed the player of what certain enemies do, he or she can figure out their behaviors and easily learn them all, without the game using a character like Megaman X's Alia to instruct the player on what to do. This element of [i]Remedy[/i] makes it a charming re-creation of the good side of games from the era of the Commodore vic-20 and 64 to the NES, with less repetition and punishing difficulty, and more variety.

My only problem was that the game was not resizeable, but simply zoomed in. Up close, it seemed less sharp. This was less of a problem and more of a slight annoyance, which disappeared when I sat back on my couch with a controller, further away from the screen.

[i]Remedy[/i] is a great demonstration of the developer's understanding of game design, and a fine example of what they can do in a very short amount of time.

On my first run, I achieved a 92% completion rate in under an hour. Following this, I spent almost the same amount of time to write my review. If nothing else does, I hope the time I took to tell you to play this game can be an indicator that you should at least try it out. After all, it's free!

24606701.review:
After seeing this game in my recommended list for several months, I decided screw it and gave it a try. Needless to say, this game was more than I ever could have expected.

The story is incredibly simple, but seeing as this game is only about an hour long, its still very satisfying and enjoyable. This game has a very large number of endings, each determined by whom you decide to marry at the end of the game, it's honestly astounding how many people you can marry, and its clear that a lot of effort and heart was put into the endings, as you can marry just about every NPC in the game, plus some stuff that isn't even NPC's! 

The game itself is litered with fun secrets, hidden rooms, secret passages, etc. Plus a short sidequest near the end. The NPC diolouge is quirky and enterntaining, all of these help increase how immersive and captivating this game is.

PR in a World of Hurt is home to some extremley addicting shoot-em-up gameplay. There are three levels of difficulty- Normal, Hard and Master. Normal mode is pretty easy, but the two higher levels provide a real challenge for fans of bullet-hell senarios or people just looking for an excuse to snap their keyboard over their knee. Attempting to get a 101% on master is seriously one of the most painful and frustrating things I've ever done, but it's still loads of fun doing so. Throughout the game, you can collect upgrades by opening chests, which make you more powerful in a variety of ways. This leads into yet another way the game excells, it is paced perfectly. Even though you get stronger as the game progresses, the enemies and situations you are put in still get progressively more difficult, starting at pushover in the begging and get to decently challenging towards the end. You never feel overpowered or that the game is rigged against you (Except in master).

Princess Remedy in a World of Hurt, while it may be very short, it's honestly one of the best experiences I've ever had on Steam, or PC gaming as a whole, and games like this are a shining beacon of the possibilities of Indie games. This game is only about 50MB, installs almost instantly, and best of all, it's absolutley free! Given this, I see no reason why anyone should not try this game out, trust me, you will not be disapointed.

24509522.review:
[h1][b]Princess Remedy in a World of Hurt[/b][/h1]

[list]
[*][b]Introducción:[/b] [i]Se trata de un videojuego en 2D, de estilo retro con graficos del tipo pixel y musica tipo 8-bits. Cuenta con 40 a 60 minutos como maximo de juego, en el que encarnaremos una princesa que acaba de terminar su preparación en las artes de la curación, empezaremos en un poblado en el que acumularemos experiencias a base de sanar los habitantes, con lo que sumaremos suficientes puntos "corazones" como para poder pasar a una nueva zona.[/i]

[*][b]Interfaz:[/b]
El videojuego cuenta con un conjunto simple y de facil entendimiento, acorde con su estilo retro. No obstante, la cantidad reducida de comandos in-game hace de que se generen ciertas incomodides sobretodo al abrir y cerrar el menu de juego y estadisticas.

[*][b]Sonido:[/b]
Para su estilo retro maneja una cantidad limitada de temas, no logrando así una ambientación acertada de los lugares en los cuales nos encontramos a lo largo de nuestro viaje. Despues de un tiempo vagando en algunas zonas, la musica de fondo empieza a irritar.

[*][b]Graficos:[/b]
Estilo retro, como se ha dicho, los graficos espectaculares no entran en esta categoria. Este videojuego esta orientado a usuarios que se sienten familiarizados con este tipo de graficas apelando a la nostalgia de los videojuegos de antaño. Si hay algo que tocar es el brillo excesivo de los colores, siendo estos muy agresivos a la vista. Saturación de colores muy lograda tipico de este estilo de videojuegos.

[*][b]In-game:[/b]
Cuenta con un sistema de batalla al puro estilo arcade de naves espaciales, con enemigos variados representando los agentes patogenos que infectan a nuestros incautos pacientes. Los "disparos" de nuestra protagonista iran evolucionando a medida de que avancemos.

Los habitantes de las distintas zonas son muy variados, desde humanos, flores y animales silvestres, hasta momias y seres extraterrestres.

La Princesa Remedios (Remedy) no esta explotada sexualmente, su atractivo es figurativo y te da la sensación de ser una mujer entusiasta, calida y de buen corazón. Esto impulsa al jugador a llegar hasta el final del videojuego, a pesar de las molestias que puedan causar algunos temas repetitivos y colores agresivos de ciertas etapas.

Debes encontrar todas las cajas con "corazones" en su interior para poder continuar, aunque algunas de estas cajas sean un "secreto" encontrarlas, dejando de ser algo meramente opcional.

Tiene un sistema de teletransporte con destino a todas las zonas del mundo, que iras desbloqueando a medida que avances en el juego. No muy util si tenemos en cuenta que la zona inicial una vez completada no se vuelve a tocar.

Jefe final con cuatro etapas, muy curioso y a pesar de que puede sonar bien, su complejidad no es mucho mayor que encuentros anteriores, no deja de ser un desafio de resistencia frente a un bombardeo constante de particulas.
[/list]

[h1][b]-RESUMEN-[/b][/h1]

[list][b]Ventajas:[/b]
[*]Free to play.
[*]Apuesta original, concepto interesante.
[*]Personajes y zonas variadas.
[*]Dificultad decente, ofrece desafíos.
[*]Mas de un final.
[*]Buena optimización.
[*]Soporte para gamepad.
[*]Tres modos de dificultad.
[*]Tres casillas de guardado.
[/list]
[list][b]Desventajas:[/b]
[*]Banda sonora escaza y en ocasiones tediosa.
[*]Elevado brillo en colores, en ocasiones irritante a la vista.
[*]Comandos reducidos, limita la fluides entre el menu/inventario y el resumen del videojuego.
[*]No hay secretos en concreto.
[/list]

[h1][b]Nota Final: 6,5 de 10.[/b][/h1]

[b]Recomendación: [h1]Totalmente positiva[/h1][/b]
[i]Un concepto original, fresco y nacido como propuesta para la[b] "Games Against Ebola"[/b] en el 2014. La protagonista logra transmitir su escencia a traves de sus acciones y singulares caracteristicas que la definen, mas una gama variada de personajes que no se creeria a priori que pudieran interactuar con nuestra princesa.[/i]

[h1]Esperemos una proxima entrega mas elaborada de esta apuesta por Ludosity (editora y desarrolladora) y Remar Games (desarrolladora).[/h1]

24473293.review:
Принцесса Лекарство в мире Боли - милая и приятная игра в ретро-стилистике.

1) [u]Сюжет[/u]: история в игре типично сказочная - принцесса Лекарство (Remedy) закончившая магическую медицинскую академию, отправляется в мир Боли (Hurtland), дабы вылечить всех тамошних жителей, а особенно местного принца, ну и получить за это королевство и суженого на выбор ([i]спойлер[/i]: [spoiler]на выбор из ВСЕХ вылеченных, то есть можно нашу героиню выдать замуж за разумный цветочек или мумию к примеру[/spoiler]).

2) [u]Геймплей[/u]: мы ходим по карте в стиле классических jRPG игр, шмонаем сундуки и лечим больных - для этого надо с ними пообщаться, и после этого расстрелять все бактерии и прочие недуги на квадратной арене (типа тех что были к примеру в  Binding of Isaac), таблетками и прочими шприцами (зависит от собранных апгрейдов). За каждого вылеченного дают сердечко, их надо собирать чтобы пройти в следующие локации на карте. В игре 3 уровня сложности, и возможность играть как с клавиатуры, так и с джойстика, и то и другое вполне удобно. Сама игра коротка и проходится примерно за час.

3) [u]Графика и звуки[/u]: и то и другое, сделано в духе ранних игр под DOS, или же под ZX Spectrum. Кто сиё видел, сможет словить ностальгию, кто нет, сможет посмотреть как игры выглядели в 80-90 годы.

[u]Как итог[/u]: игрушка милая, приятная, короткая в прохождении, и не самая сложная. Тем кто любит ретро рекомендую однозначно.
9 успешных лечений из 10

What can I say about this game that hasn't already been said? Not much, since it's so short. But don't take its brevity as a negative aspect about it. The game is charming, funny, and engaging in a way that is greatly amusing in the short term but would likely wear thin after much more than two hours or so. The plot is well-conceived, though simplistic, and it is really interesting to see a pacifist, shoot-em-up, bullet hell, RPG-type game. I'd recommend this game for a rainy afternoon or perhaps a day when you're feeling ill and staying home. Who knows, perhaps Princess Remedy might have just the thing for you.

Wow, simply, wow. This game was fun, creative, full of charm, funny, and I am seriously surprised it's free. I would gladly pay 5 maybe 10 bucks for this game. Yeah, it lasts about 2 hours tops for one run through (at 101%, mind you) but this game is so fun, I plan on playing it again. 
I actually came in WANTING to dislike this game, I really did. "Look at this game with its stupid bright colors and its stupid stupidness" Said I, waiting to just rek this game in this review, and then 5 minutes later my face is glued to the screen ready to get that 101% playthrough done. Now, to be fair, the colors do get hard on the eyes after a while, but this game is so short it doesn't really give your eyes a chance to get hurt due to prolonged exposure. And the music, not that great but heck, it didn't hurt my ears and over all I felt no need to turn it off, which is a plus in my book.
If you need a game to help you kill some time, please, do yourself a favor and download this game.

After those ten minutes, my eyes adjusted, and the problem was no more. The bullet hell mini-games are pretty damn unique, as far as I can tell. There's a deep(ish) backstory between Remedy and Frallan(her friend from Medical School), and, minutes after being horrified at there being 64 possible endings, I could marry anyone I wanted, and could do so again, and again without having to play through the game 63 more times! Also, guess who my first bride was(that should give you a clue!). All in all, this game got me hooked for two days straight, and I liked it more than many 10-20 dollar games of a similar calibre. And when I found there was going to be a pre-quel- I grinned for minutes! One last thing- this game was made for a charity event called Games Against Ebola. That is reason alone to play it! So, I urge anyone reading this to give Princess Remedy in a World of Hurt a try- you WON'T regret it!

Basic premise of the game: You're Princess Remedy tasked with "healing" all the people of the world, with the end goal being the prince. You talk to a person, find out their ailment (anything from a broken heart to a stubbed toe) and heal them. Healing consists of a short one screen shooter defeating various enemies. Some enemies are stationary, some move around, some are behind a block, etc. As you travel around you'll get upgrades like faster shot, better health regeneration, etc.

23914851.review:
I'm now a Game Master.

This title has been granted to me by the game as I completed every possible challenge in this wonderfully sweet game.

A simple, short and sweet game about a princess with the power to heal people from their ailments, be they physical or emotional. She does that by entering "Healing Mode +++", which causes her to face their ailments as enemies in combat, which works in a bullet hell mechanic, with auto fire as you move.

The difficulty is just right. If you are in for a nice, simple experience, Normal mode is just fine. If you want the story, but also want an extra challenge, Hard is for you. If you want to feel a trully brutal experience, try completing the game on Master. I did and I feel mostly satisfied, now only waiting for the sequel to ever launch.

With exactly 4 hours of game time and managing to complete the campaing twice (one on hard and one on Master), I can assure you that this is easily a game worth even buying, yet it's still free. Go, give it a try, I highly recommend it.

I love how this retro-RPG-lite turned combat into a mission of mercy by making all the enemies viruses plaguing the good people of Hurtland, who let's face it, should have expected this when they settled on that name. The graphics are pre-NES simplistic, akin to early 80s computer games, but the lo-fi approach doesn't detract from the presentation. The music is peppy and light, a bit incongruous with the bare-bones graphics but I'd rather have ho-hum graphics and fun music than the reverse. There's not much story but the dialogue is cute, and there's a silly surprise at the end that makes the entire experience all the more delightful. And I didn't even find all the secrets!
Bottom line: it costs nothing and you can finish it in less than an hour. Totally worth it.
